channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Environment

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The council area that is home to the Prime Minister and one of Australia's most prominent climate change sceptics will probably vote for carbon neutrality by 2030.
item.title: PM's home shire sets steep carbon emissions reduction target

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The plan to use Kyoto 'carryover credits' towards Australia's Paris carbon emissions reduction pledge effectively halves the country's emissions reduction pledge.
item.title: Kyoto credit use will halve cut to emissions: Climate Change Authority

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: A government biodiversity survey of a World Heritage zone to be flooded if the Warragamba Dam wall is raised was so rushed its koala component involved peering into just 90 trees.
item.title: Wildlife survey of dam flood zone found wanting, leaked report says

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Summer-like temperatures and warm seas are predicted to offer a welcome distraction from coronavirus concerns.
item.title: 'Wave of heat' set to arrive in Sydney

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: A clutch of rare turtles has hatched over the past month thanks to a new breeding program that may help save the breed.
item.title: Tiny hatchlings giving hope to endangered species

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The reduction in emissions will probably be amplified the longer the slowdown in air traffic lasts, and as related travel activities also shrink.
item.title: Emissions to fall by millions of tonnes as coronavirus stalls economy

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The Australian Conservation Foundation will test in court the government's failure to activate the so-called water trigger when assessing the proposed coal mine.
item.title: Morrison government faces legal challenge over Adani pipeline plan

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Sydneysiders can expect several more gloomy days before sunshine returns although big swells generated by Tropical Cyclone Gretel may pose dangers for beachgoers.
item.title: 'Stream showers' for Sydney as Cyclone Gretel stirs a beach battering

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Shifting NSW's $600 billion economy towards net zero carbon emissions will generate many opportunities as new industries emerge but also require careful policy co-ordination and communication.
item.title: Risk and reward in decarbonising NSW economy, says chief scientist

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: In the 10 years since Saigon retired from a long circus career, the female elephant has had little companionship save a flock of sheep, a donkey, a miniature pony, and lately, three water buffaloes named Larry, Curly and Moe.
item.title: 'Grand old dame' to get elephant companions after circus life

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: Recreational fishers are appealing to farmers to work with them to save the millions of fish killed in irrigation pipes each year.
item.title: Plea to save 'hundreds of millions' of fish killed by irrigation pumps

item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Farrelly
item.description: The mayor of Paris is implementing a vision for the city that embodies the good life - and we should learn from her.
item.title: C'est la vie: Paris shows the world how to live

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Sydney's run of mild and sunny early autumn weather will turn cool and damp as a tropical cyclone steers moist onshore winds over most of eastern Australia.
item.title: Damp spell ahead for Sydney as another tropical cyclone pulls in rain

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: Beekeepers predict it could take at least a decade for heavily burnt bushlandÂ along Australia's east coast to bounce back with the pollen and nectar needed for honey production.
item.title: Bushfire 'devastation' for beekeepers as honey production plummets

item.description: When thereâ€™s no rain, Australian farmers fall back on their optimism.
item.title: Have faith in us, say farmers

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Earthwork dams along the river will be removed in coming weeks to ensure powerful flows can flush all the way down to the Murray.
item.title: 'Wonderful' flows prompt removal of Lower Darling River temporary dams

item.dc:creator: Taylor Denny
item.description: Two chimpanzees have undergone their routine check-ups, one that's remarkably similar to humans.
item.title: Chimps get the all-clear in Taronga Zoo health check

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Analysis published on Thursday by Carbon Tracker also fund that by 2030 at the latest, new wind and solar farms will be cheaper to build than existing coal plants.
item.title: Renewables to make $1 trillion in new coal-fired plants uncompetitive

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: The Bellinger River snapping turtle that was almost wiped out by a virus in 2015 is now on the road to recovery, with 35 new hatchlings.
item.title: Baby boom for rare turtle on the edge of extinction

item.description: "This is a dark day," the Hirola Conservation Program said of the discovery of the skeletal remains of the adult female and one of her calves.
item.title: Rare white giraffes found dead in Kenya, most likely killed by poachers

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Residents of far-western NSW are celebrating the arrival of the first major river flows to reach the Menindee Lakes since 2016.
item.title: 'Like a kid at Christmas': Menindee Lakes finally start to fill again

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The world's vegetation may be getting a boost from rising levels of carbon dioxide but a lot of the extra growth turns out to be junk food for grasshoppers.
item.title: Declining health on the prairie: why more plant growth may be bad news

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The Indian Ocean weather pattern that contributed to eastern Australia's intense drought is becoming more common because of climate change.
item.title: More drought in Australia's future as weather patterns change

item.description: Even the cost of small reactors is prohibitive.
item.title: Supporters of nuclear need a reality check: it's staggeringly expensive

item.description: The state government has been slow to the party on single-use plastic bags but could be laying the foundations for some big picture improvements.
item.title: NSW shows promise on tackling one of world's most complex environmental crises

item.description: For Australia, the choice between danger and opportunity is clear, and that choice must be made now.
item.title: Be honest Australia, you're not 'meeting and beating' your emissions targets

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The degraded Macquarie Marshes have suffered from drought for years - and just as waterflows recover comes a push for a weir.
item.title: 'Terrible' new weir proposed for river as flows resume

item.description: Andrew Leeds is among the growing band of backyard beekeepers making their own honey.
item.title: Former rugby great gets a buzz out of bees

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: Australia is the driest continent, among the most intensive users of water, and rivers are expected to dry out dramatically in coming decades.
item.title: 'We need a serious conversation': River flows could decline 40% in Australia's foodbowl

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The future work of dozens of researchers seeking to develop a low-carbon 'energy superpower' vision hangs in the balance after support from both the German and Australian governments was halted.
item.title: 'Energy superpower' hub hopes dim as Germany, Australia stop funding

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: Life-giving water is surging through rivers in far western NSW on its way to the desperately dry Lower Darling River.
item.title: Desperately dry Lower Darling River gets a decent drink

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Extending AGL's ailing Liddell power station beyond the already delayed closure date of 2023 could pose a "major concern" for the health and safety of workers at the plant.Â
item.title: Extending Liddell a 'major concern' for worker safety, Kean says

item.description: Drought has failed to diminish the spirit of Murrurundiâ€™s resilient community, says a veteran farmer.
item.title: A wellspring of kindness in the face of drought

item.description: A cross-party upper house inquiry has recommended lifting the prohibition on uranium mining in NSW - and the Deputy Premier writes why this is the state's chance to move to nuclear power.
item.title: Why small nuclear reactors could be NSW's energy - and emissions - solution

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Record sea-surface temperatures in much of the Great Barrier Reef region have intensified the risks that coral bleaching already underway could develop into another mass bleaching event within weeks.
item.title: Record February heat pushes Reef corals closer to big bleaching event

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Australia's extreme bushfire season was at least 30 per cent more likely than a century ago because of climate change, and the risks of a repeat will rise four-fold if global temperatures exceed a two-degree rise.Â
item.title: Climate change made 'really scary' fire extremes a third more likely

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The University of NSW will divest its holdings of fossil fuel company investments by 2025, joining other academic institutions seekingÂ to "make a contribution to dealing with the climate crisis".
item.title: UNSW to jettison fossil fuel investments by 2025 'at the latest'

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: More than 12,000 kilometres of Australia's sandy beaches are threatened by coastal erosion by the end of the century, with greater losses predicted if greenhouse gas emissions remain high.
item.title: Thousands of kilometres of Australia's beaches at risk from rising seas

item.description: When fifth generation Queensland farmer, Ben Usher, tells his son Toby that grass once used to grow
item.title: The drain of the drought: â€œWeâ€™re all in it togetherâ€

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Our hottest season is not like the one many of us grew up with and is placing infrastructure under major strain.
item.title: Summers are starting earlier, finishing later and winter is in retreat

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Conservation efforts in NSW to stop more species becoming extinct in the wake of this season's unparalleledÂ bushfires require more than half a billion dollars over the coming four years.
item.title: 'Teetering on the brink': Half a billion dollars sought to aid wildlife recovery

item.description: It's been 30 years since the first national Clean-up Australia Day. We revisit the first one held in 1990.
item.title: From the Archives, 1990: That's another fine mess gone

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: When Pip Kiernan's father Ian organised a community rubbish-collecting day called Clean Up Sydney Harbour 31 years ago, he was worried that nobody would come.Â
item.title: 'He really struck a chord': Clean Up Australia going strong after 30 years

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: A parliamentary inquiry into the coal seam gas industry has found that just two of 16 recommendations for the controversial industry have been implemented more than five years after the Chief Scientist made them.
item.title: NSW's CSG inquiry finds most recommendations ignored

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: With just a couple of days to the end of summer, the Harbour City will probably end February with temperatures averaging about 27.3 degrees for the season.
item.title: Australia's hot, smoky summer comes to a soggy end in Sydney

item.dc:creator: John Hewson
item.description: While major global financial institutions declare their exit from coal, Australian politicians dither.
item.title: Global finance leaves Australia behind in the march to net-zero emissions

item.description: During a recent warm stretch, snow cover markedly declined as melt ponds formed on Eagle Island, Antarctica, and nearby ice shelves.
item.title: Antarctic heatwave melted 20 per cent of an island's snow cover in days

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Australia's bushfires exposed deficiencies in the climate models that are struggling to pick out changes in rainfall and fire weather trends, scientists say.
item.title: 'Extraordinary' fires burnt at historical size, beyond climate projections

item.description: For climate skeptics, it's hard to compete with the youthful appeal of global phenomenon Greta Thunberg. But one US think tank hopes it's found an answer in 19-year-old Naomi Seibt: the anti-Greta.
item.title: The anti-Greta: US conservative think tank takes on the global phenomenon

item.dc:creator: The Herald's View
item.description: The ALP has committed to a sensible, responsible target for carbon emissions. But the Coalition is spurning bipartisanship in favour of political opportunism.
item.title: Coalition must follow Albanese on target of net zero by 2050
